results.title: Woman gathers food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alcheringa”.
To the women falls the task of collecting supplementary foods - such as witchetty grubs and yams. Use is made of a sharply pointed stick to dig under bark for grubs and to kill a lizard which wanders across their path; also to dig for yams. The daughter accompanies her mother on her daily walk and learns the art of food gathering.

results.title: Making a bark canoe (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
A detailed description of the processes involved in making a bark canoe. Includes the proper way to remove the heavy water-soaked bark, the steam heating to make it pliable to shape the stern and bow, and the way to sew the ends together.

results.title: Turtle hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Alcheringa”
Shows how Australia’s Aborigines lived hundreds of years ago. Shows unique methods of locating and hunting turtles by wading into shallow pools and feeling for the hard shells with bare feet, grasping their necks by hand, and roasting in hot ashes.

results.title: Gurrawilla
results.creator_credit: Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
At one time, Marshall lived with the Aborigines in Arnhem Land, and he tells us how he became known as ‘Gurrawilla’. He also describes in a light-hearted manner tales of his childhood.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre

results.title: On writing
results.creator_credit: Alexander Milsky, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
Though afflicted by sickness and suffering at an early age, Marshall had a happy childhood. He began to write at the age of ten. He read widely and was influenced by various authors, though his stories usually begin from small everyday incidents or remarks. He offers some advice to young writers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alexander Milsky, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre

results.title: Life and influences
results.creator_credit: Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
Alan Marshall describes his early life, the loneliness because of his handicap, and how he overcame this by faith and determination. He tells in an amusing way how people and incidents gave him a store of material that inspired his creative ability, and shaped his philosophy.

results.title: Three Mile Creek
results.brief_description:
One of 6 works selected by AIM director David Atkinson as representing the best interactive work produced by the AIM centre up until 2004. Three Mile Creek is a collection of anecdotal accounts inspired by an experience of growing up in rural northern NSW. The aim is to transport the participant into what is a distinctively Australian time and place, with the child who lives on the farm as their guide.
A contemplative approach is the key to appreciating the stories. Music, dialogue and soundscape evoke the richness of the environment and create the sense of being there
